headline: Ruben Amorim changes his tune with new verdict on Kobbie Mainoo's Man Utd future
body: Ruben Amorim has insisted that Kobbie Mainoo is the 'future of Manchester United' - and made it clear that he's unlikely to depart in January. Mainoo, 20, has been heavily linked with a move away, having pushed to leave United on loan in the final days of the summer transfer window.

European giants Napoli and Bayern Munich hold an interest but despite not giving him a single start in the Premier League this season, Amorim views him as part of his long-term plans. It comes just a week after the Red Devils boss told Mainoo that he needs to 'fight for his job' before a calf injury ruled him out of last Sunday's 2-1 defeat away to Aston Villa.
"He's going to be the future of Manchester United, that is my feeling," Amorim declared. "He just needs to wait for his chance and everything can change in football in two days."

The United manager added: "Kobbie Mainoo will have the opportunity he has all the time. He played in different positions; he can do that [defensive midfield] position, he can play if we play with three, he can play like we play in the last game - the position of Mason Mount in this game [against Villa]."

Amorim then played down the chances of Mainoo leaving Old Trafford next month, saying: "If we are not getting someone, it is hard to leave. Even with a full squad we are shorter [in terms of players] for something that can happen here so it's going to be hard for someone to leave the club if we don't get a substitution."

Mainoo will miss the Boxing Day clash with Newcastle because of his injury. The timing is especially frustrating given that Bruno Fernandes is also sidelined and Casemiro missed the Villa game through suspension.
This season, Mainoo has only started one match. That was United's humiliating loss against League Two side Grimsby Town in the Carabao Cup in August.

Also in his pre-Newcastle press conference, Amorim confirmed that no decisions have been made regarding the futures of Casemiro and Harry Maguire, who are both out of contract in June. "There is no decision," the Portuguese added.

"We have a lot to do and we need to understand what is going to happen the next season, because we need to understand if there is European games what we are doing. We have so much to do in this moment. We are not thinking about that. I am really happy with them but I don't know what is going to happen."

headline: ‘I left Man Utd without even speaking to the manager – he made me feel unloved’
body: Andreas Pereira confessed that he deliberately avoided speaking with Erik ten Hag before leaving Manchester United to avoid being persuaded to stay. The Brazilian midfielder, currently starring at Palmeiras, made the switch from PSV's youth setup for the opportunity to work under legendary manager Sir Alex Ferguson.

At that time, Ten Hag served as assistant manager at the Dutch club and made considerable efforts to keep the promising youngster. Pereira ultimately made the move to Old Trafford in 2014 and made his senior bow that same year in a League Cup clash against MK Dons.

Despite an eight-year association with Manchester, the midfielder managed just 75 appearances and had loan spells at four separate clubs. Following his final temporary stint at Flamengo in 2021, Pereira felt it was time for a fresh start and was poised to join Fulham for approximately £10million.

However, the midfielder chose to ignore then-United manager Ten Hag due to a previous encounter with the boss at his former youth club. Speaking on Rio Ferdinand Presents, the Brazilian confessed he felt unwanted during his Manchester tenure.
Pereira said: "This was when I came back to England [after my loan]. Erik ten Hag, he worked at PSV when I was 16 years old.

"Before leaving for United, the [PSV] president and Erik ten Hag came to speak to me and my dad and said, 'Look everything is set up for you at PSV, if you stay here you're going to play in the first team.' But I'd just been to United and spoke with Fergie. I was like, 'I'm going to United.'

"That's why I didn't want to speak to Erik because I knew him and I knew that, at the time, it was always a conversation, like, 'Andreas, stay here. You're not going to play every game, maybe one game in every three, you'll be around the squad.' That's not what I wanted, I wanted to play."

Reflecting on his choice to leave Old Trafford, the now 29-year-old said: "Leaving United, you're like, 'Am I really going to do this? Am I sure?' In the end, you're never 100 per cent sure, really. Sometimes you think stay and have another go. Other times, you have to leave.

"I wanted to play, after Covid, I wanted to play. I was going crazy, wanting to play in the Premier League. I wanted to show that I was good enough, I was very close to joining [Everton] and suddenly my father called me and said, 'Andreas, you never played in Brazil, you're Brazilian.'

"I wanted to play in Brazil and want to feel loved. I didn't feel the love that I thought I should get. I wanted to feel loved by my own people, play close to my family and enjoy football. Everyone at United said, 'You're crazy, you'll stay in Brazil, you'll never come back to Europe.'"
These days, Pereira plays his football in his homeland of Brazil and has featured 20 times this season for Palmeiras - scoring two goals and providing one assist.

headline: Morgan Rogers 'would be dream signing' for Man Utd ahead of January window
body: Morgan Rogers has been named as Manchester United's 'dream signing' ahead of the January transfer window. Rogers, 23, is in the form of his life and continued his purple patch during Aston Villa's 2-1 win at home to United last Sunday.

The England international scored both of Villa's goals; the first a wonderful curling effort from distance while the second was a similar finish from closer range. The victory made it 10 in a row for title hopefuls Villa and, after Bruno Fernandes went off injured, showed Red Devils boss Ruben Amorim the kind of player that he's missing.

That's the verdict of former United striker Louis Saha, who wants United to make an ambitious bid for Rogers. "In January, I see a need for a replacement who can spark our midfield creativity," Saha told FootItalia.

"In addition to Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount, there's a need for speed in the creativity there. I think Conor Gallagher would've been a good signing, he has the legs and the power, I'd also love to see Morgan Rogers at United.
"He definitely has this power, he reminds me a bit of Joelinton. That kind of power, and still very technical, and able to go forward. Having that kind of presence in the midfield is so important.
"I see Rogers as being able to actually bomb forward, but also get pressed and keep the ball, giving time for other players to move into different positions. He is the type of player United need."

"It's a very interesting profile that's rare in the sense that a lot of players are very athletic, but in terms of making the right choice with that athleticism, that's not easy. So I can see Rogers as being a dream signing."

Notably, Rogers has a connection with United's director of football, Jason Wilcox, from their time at Manchester City. Wilcox was running City's academy when they paid £4.3million to sign a 16-year-old Rogers from West Bromwich Albion in 2019, so the forward will be no stranger to the United hierarchy.

Various City academy graduates are flourishing in the Premier League, the most prominent being Cole Palmer. United would no-doubt love to reap the rewards of their rivals' oversight but if anyone comes knocking for Rogers, Villa will drive a hard bargain.

"Morgan Rogers is performing fantastically, but he has started the season not getting (goalscoring) numbers but playing well," Unai Emery said after beating United. "Always doing his task, always with the commitment he's showing, with the attitude he has, played each match.

"Today he did the same and scored goals, of course. He is the protagonist. I'm so, so happy because he's a fighter. He's a good guy, very good guy. His commitment with Aston Villa is massive, and his attitude every day is really fantastic. And when he's getting numbers like today, of course we are very proud of everybody, but especially today with him."

headline: Team news from all 20 Premier League teams as Man Utd, Arsenal and Liverpool face issues
body: The festive fixtures are finally here and all 20 of the Premier League's teams are set for action this week - although only two will lock horns on Boxing Day this year.

The majority of the next round of fixtures are set to take place on December 27, Manchester United and Newcastle will meet at Old Trafford on Boxing Day at 8pm before their rivals follow suit the following day, with all the big boys in action.

Ben Gannon-Doak, Tyler Adams, Veljko Milosavljevic are all set to be unavailable for the Cherries trip to Brentford on Saturday. Beyond those three, Andoni Iraola has reported no fresh injury concerns.

The Gunners will once again be without long-term absentee Gabriel. He could be joined on the sidelines by Piero Hincapie, who picked up an injury in the Carabao Cup triumph over Crystal Palace in midweek.
Cristian Mosquera, Ben White White, Kai Havertz and Max Dowman are also out.
Evann Guessand has linked up with the Ivory Coast for the Africa Cup of Nations. Ross Barkley, Tyrone Mings and Pau Torres are also out, while Harvey Elliott is also a doubt.
Keith Andrews will be without Frank Onyeka and Dango Outtara, who are at the Africa Cup of Nations. Josh Dasilva, Fabio Carvalho and Antoni Milambo are Brentford's other absentees.
Carlos Baleba is one of four players expected to miss their game at Arsenal. Stefanos Tzimas, Adam Webster and Solly March will also be unavailable this weekend.

Axel Tuanzebe and Lyle Foster are both at the Africa Cup of Nations but other Clarets stars are also set to miss out against Everton. Connor Roberts, Jordan Beyer, Zeki Amdouni are injured while Hannibal Mejbri is banned, but Maxime Esteve is back in contention.

Ruben Colwill, Romeo Lavia and Dario Essugo are unavailable for Chelsea's game with Aston Villa. Willian Estevao could return, though, after sitting out the Blues' last two matches, while Liam Delap may also feature.
Ismaila Sarr misses out due to the Africa Cup of Nations. Daichi Kamada, Cheick Doucoure and Daniel Munoz all remain injured and will play no part on Sunday when Palace play Tottenham.

David Moyes will have to make do without Iliman Ndiaye and Idrissa Gueye (Africa Cup of Nations) against Burnley. Jarrad Branthwaite and Seamus Coleman are both sidelined with hamstring injuries and will also miss out.

Harry Wilson could be a doubt after limping off in the win over Nottingham Forest on Monday. Rodrigo Muniz and Ryan Sessegnon are still absent while Calvin Bassey, Samuel Chukwueze and Alex Iwobi are all at the Africa Cup of Nations with Nigeria.
Lukas Nmecha could return for Leeds but their Sunday game vs Sunderland will come too soon for Sean Longstaff and Daniel James.

Alexander Isak is the big Liverpool absentee after undergoing surgery on a leg fracture earlier this week. Joe Gomez and Wataru Endo have both been ruled out while Mohamad Salah is at the Africa Cup of Nations.
Dominik Szoboszlai misses out through suspension after accumulating five yellow cards but Cody Gakpo and Conor Bradley are '50-50' and could play some part.
Mateo Kovacic is out for Manchester City while Jeremy Doku, Oscar Bobb, Rodri and John Stones are all doubts. Rayan Ait-Nouri and Omar Marmoush are at the Africa Cup of Nations.
Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo are likely to miss out with the former definitely sidelined. Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt are doubts.
Sven Botman, Kieran Trippier, Emil Krafth, Dan Burn and Tino Livramento are all ruled out for Newcastle but Nick Pope could be fit enough to return to the squad.
Ola Aina, Ibrahim Sangare, Willy Boly, Chris Wood and Ryan Yates will play no part in Saturday's home game against Manchester City.
Luke O'Nien is still suspended for the Black Cats, who have SIX players at the Africa Cup of Nations: Arthur Masuaku, Habib Diarra, Noah Sadiki, Reinildo, Chemsdine Talbi and Bertrand Traore.
Cristian Romero and Xavi Simons are both suspended after being sent off in the defeat against Liverpool. Yves Bissouma and Papa Mate Sarr are both at the Africa Cup of Nations.
Aaron Wan-Bissaka and El Hadji Malick Diouf are the Hammers' only two absentees with both players at the Africa Cup of Nations.
Yerson Mosquera is back but Wolves will be without captain Toti Gomes for their game with Liverpool due to a hamstring issue.

headline: Three of the world's richest footballers played for Arsenal, Man Utd and Chelsea
body: Becoming a Premier League footballer often means your financial concerns are over. As fans know, players are paid astronomical sums to play the game we love.

Even after retiring from the sport many ex-players head down the road of punditry, coaching or other business ventures, to highly lucrative ends. However, three players from Manchester United, Arsenal and Chelsea have gone on, or will go on, to extraordinary wealth after hanging up their boots.

The French striker, now 47, played for United from 2004 to 2008. He enjoyed a hugely successful career at Old Trafford, winning two league titles, the Champions League and League Cup under Sir Alex Ferguson.

Saha's company 'AxisStars' is now worth a stunning £4.3billion. The company, which was co-founded by Kate Hamer, is in charge of connecting relationships between "professional athletes and entertainers, their peers and trusted partners".

According to several sources, over 550 ex-athletes are connected with the firm. Saha admitted he gets inquiries from people asking for his advice and was candid in saying that starting up AxisStars has surpassed anything he's done in his footballing career.

"I still get asked for advice by different people on a daily basis," he once told The Guardian. "For instance, my agent called me to say he had a talented French footballer who he wants to bring to England, and asked me for advice on how to create a tailor-made training programme. I put him in touch with people I used to work with."

Saha scored 42 goals in 124 games, even though his time at United was blighted by injuries. By the time he hung up his boots in 2013 at the age of 35, Saha had played for Metz, Newcastle, Everton, Tottenham Hotspur, Sunderland and Lazio.
Former Arsenal midfielder Flamini founded GF Biochemicals nine years before his retirement. He became CEO later on and now has a reported net worth of around £10bn
He even took a more hands-on role following his retirement from football. Becoming CEO saw him take a 60% stake that cemented his status as one of the wealthiest men to ever play football.

GF Biochemicals aims to provide a more environmentally friendly alternative to petrochemicals, which would allow the manufacture of products without harming the environment. Flamini has previously explained his career change following retirement. "As a child I had two passions: football and sustainability," he said.

The French star made 246 appearances in two spells for the Gunners, before leaving on a free transfer in 2017. The now 41-year-old had two spells at Arsenal. The first came between 2004 and 2008 and he later made a return to the Emirates Stadium in 2013.

During his time with the club, he won five trophies including three FA Cups and two Community Shields. Arsenal was not the only Premier League team he played for either, with the midfielder spending a short spell with Crystal Palace following his second exit from Arsenal.

Ex-Chelsea youth player Bolkiah is the son of Prince Jefri Bolkiah and nephew of the Sultan of Brunei, who is reported to be worth around £37bn. Bolkiah is the heir to a £15 bn fortune meaning football icons such as Cristiano Ronaldo, David Beckham and Lionel Messi's bank balances all pale in comparison.

Former Chelsea team-mate, Ruben Sammut, once claimed Bolkiah was as humble as they come. Previously speaking to The Athletic, Sammut said: "You would never ever have thought he was something like the 12th in line to the throne. You would not have thought of him as royalty."
After spells with Chelsea and Southampton. Bolkiah later signed for Leicester City but despite being with the Foxes for four years, he never made a senior appearance.
After leaving the UK, Bolkiah played for Mariitimo in Portugal before moving to Thailand where he played for Chonburi FC and Ratchaburi. He has also earned six caps for Brunei.

body: In a controversial move, there’s only one Premier League game scheduled for Boxing Day. When the festive season’s fixtures were announced in October, the Premier League said the changes were made due to the ‘expansion of European club competitions’ and ‘how the calendar falls’.

“The Premier League would like to acknowledge the circumstances that have led to a reduced number of matches on Boxing Day this season, impacting an important tradition in English football,” it said. “There are now several challenges to Premier League fixture scheduling rooted in the expansion of European club competitions, which led to a revision of our domestic calendar ahead of last season, including changes to the FA Cup.

“This ultimately left the Premier League as a 33-weekend competition, fewer than previous seasons, despite being a 380-match competition since 1995. With fewer weekends to work with, the league is bound by how the calendar falls.”

headline: Scott McTominay's stance on Man Utd return as 'issues' emerge at Napoli
body: Scott McTominay is reportedly considering a return to the Premier League, although Manchester United are not necessarily on his radar.

The Scotland international has seen a resurgence in his career since leaving United in 2024, netting 12 goals and clinching the Serie A title in his debut season. The 29-year-old has been a key player for both club and country, often scoring crucial last-minute goals.
However, according to The Sun, this season has seen some challenges for Napoli. An insider revealed: "Scott loves elements of Italian life and had a wonderful first season.

"But the passion of the fans can be a blessing, but also make things difficult. He is treated as a god over there, but it means he finds it difficult to do simple things when he's not training. The attention can be suffocating."

In light of this, speculation has been rife linking McTominay with various clubs, including Barcelona, Tottenham and Newcastle. The midfielder is reportedly open to a return to England and might even consider a reunion with United if the circumstances align.

Chatting to the BBC last summer about his new Italian adventure, McTominay enthused: "The people in Naples are incredible, they're so passionate and everywhere you go there are people who say 'Forza Napoli' and they want to speak to you and have a conversation and that inspires you every time you go on the pitch because they care.

"It's different, a totally different way of life over there - the way you eat, the way you live and all that. It gives you more mental strength. I've always lived very close to my mum, so I could go whenever I wanted.

"Now, living 1,500 miles away, I can't just pop home to see my mum, my family, my sister and my kids so it's different, but in life you sometimes have to step out of your comfort zone and I've always prided myself on that.
"I would never want to be in my comfort zone, and if I can go away anywhere and establish myself and do well, why not? Who's to stop me doing that?"

These sentiments of stretching his boundaries might suggest that McTominay is open to testing himself in a foreign league, and with recent rumours linking him to Barcelona, he could potentially join former teammate Marcus Rashford in Spain.

headline: Barcelona 'working on' Man Utd transfer as Marcus Rashford's future stance clear
body: Hansi Flick reportedly wants Barcelona to prioritise signing Marcus Rashford from Manchester United on a permanent basis. Reports suggest La Liga's leaders are already working on a deal to extend the England international's stay at Camp Nou beyond his current loan.

The 28-year-old forward joined the Spanish heavyweights on a season-long spell during this summer's transfer window. That move materialised after falling out of favour under Ruben Amorim, with limited game time at United leading to a stint at Aston Villa.

There are now suggestions from other sources that financially troubled Barcelona could make Rashford's move permanent for a fee in the region of £26million. On Christmas Day, reporter Matteo Moretto claimed that Hansi Flick has not only made Rashford a primary target for the Catalan club, but that they are also actively working on making his deal permanent.

Rashford has been under the spotlight since his move to La Liga, following a dip in form at Old Trafford, despite having established himself as a key player for United. Since joining Barcelona, Rashford has scored seven goals and provided eight assists in his first 24 appearances, with four of those goals coming in the Champions League.

The 28-year-old recently expressed his ambition to win trophies with Barcelona and his desire to continue his career in Catalonia. He told SPORT in an interview: "I'm adapting very well to the club and the city.
"From the moment I arrived, I felt that everyone welcomed me very well. For me, the reason I'm here is to help the team win trophies.
"Last season was fantastic, but in life, everything happens very quickly, things change, and the goal is to repeat the successes. I'm totally focused on this.

"With the staff and the teammates, everything is fantastic, I can't complain. Of course, what I want is to stay at Barca. It's an end goal, but it's not the reason why I'm training hard and giving it my best.
"The purpose is to win. Barca is a huge, fantastic club, built to win titles."
Rashford continued: "There is pressure here, but it is not a negative pressure. It's the one you want as a player, the one I want and have always wanted as a footballer.
"I can't be in a place where important objectives are not demanded of you. For me, it is more difficult to be motivated and give my best at a club where the demand is not maximum.
"I'm in the perfect place and environment to continue my journey as a football player, so I just try to do my best every day and help the team win. We'll see what happens next summer."

headline: David Beckham's private three-word message to Luke Littler that showed his true colours
body: Sir David Beckham was among the throngs of supportive celebs to reach out to Luke Littler following his World Darts Championship win. And the contents showcased the Manchester United icon's caring side away from the spotlight.

Littler, 18, has transformed the face of darts during his two years playing on the PDC circuit. And he was only too aware of his impact after an England great like Beckham got in touch to congratulate him on his maiden world title almost 12 months ago.

The incident will have been particularly surreal for Littler considering he's a United fan with a deep appreciation of Beckham's legacy. 'Golden Balls' was hardly alone in sending 'The Nuke' well wishes upon clinching the crown at Alexandra Palace, but he may have been up there with the most meaningful.

The teenager continued: "It goes to show what I have done for the sport, not only for myself but for the other hundreds of professionals out there. Just to see the likes of David Beckham watching it feels crazy."

Littler also revealed Beckham contacted him in the build-up to his first final in January 2024, saying: "Before the final he sent me a message saying, 'Good luck, Luke - once a Red, always a Red.' That was class."

That number grew to 4.8m people when including NOW TV viewers and others streaming the event. That represented a 143 per cent increase on the previous year, underlining the influence Littler brought with him.

It's no coincidence the PDC has since made the decision to inflate the prize money on offer at Alexandra Palace since then. This year saw the total prize pot double to £5m, with £1m of that going to the champion, up from £500,000 in previous years.

So Littler isn't the only one in the darts economy benefiting from the extra eyeballs he brings. Indeed, every player who manages to punch a ticket to the World Championship has won before even throwing a dart.

The Nuke has sailed through to the third round of this year's competition almost without even breaking a sweat. He beat Darius Labanauskas in the first round before eliminating David Davies, albeit with some shaky moments against the latter.

Davies had a chance to take the first set before fluffing his lines in the crucial moment. Littler seized upon the opportunity to win 3-0 again and will now face Mensur Suljovic in the next round on Saturday.

There's an aura around Littler now that means a second straight World Championship wouldn't bring the same sense of surprise. Nonetheless, he may well look forward to see which celebrities reach out in the event he successfully defends his crown.

headline: Ruben Amorim made his feelings on four Man Utd players clear as finger of blame pointed
body: Several senior players in the Manchester United dressing room have felt the full force of Ruben Amorim's anger since his arrival at Old Trafford. The Red Devils have experienced a mixed campaign thus far, with victories over Liverpool and Crystal Palace standing out as bright spots for the club.

Yet defeats against Everton, Brentford and Manchester City have prompted Amorim to single out certain players for criticism, something he has shown no hesitation in doing since taking the reins. Club captain Bruno Fernandes was among those to face the Portuguese manager's fury early in his spell, following his dismissal in a 2-0 defeat to Wolves last season.

The midfielder picked up a second booking and was sent off in the second half, prompting Amorim to highlight the problems caused by the red card. He said: "It's so tough to win games in this league with 11 men. With 10 men, it's more difficult. So we have to focus on that."
Reports also suggested that the boss deliberately blanked his skipper as he trudged off the pitch. Nevertheless, Amorim acknowledged that Fernandes was equally disappointed by the dismissal.

He said: "I am always frustrated with the red card, but it can happen as he always want to go for the ball. It is not like he wants to stop the player with a yellow. He wanted to go for the ball, the guy got there first and there is a contact and that thing is tough on him also."

This season, Patrick Dorgu, Matheus Cunha and Leny Yoro have all felt the force of Amorim's frustration. Most recently, the manager took issue with defender Yoro after he gave away a penalty against Crystal Palace in November, accusing the youngster of overthinking.

Pointing to the French defender's age, Amorim said: "Of course, I also spoke with him because he thinks too much. He makes the mistakes in the game and then he struggles because he's too young and he wants to do everything so well. And he's growing.

"He's growing in one moment that everyone here is growing with games, with setbacks, so it's not easy for him as a young guy. And of course, he cannot give that to the people, the way he came to the bench. So, he understands that, but he was really frustrated."

He added: "On the good side, it shows that he cares and he was knowing that was not the best game, but he did some things well, and I show him that also, so he's fit and ready for the next challenge."

Fellow defender Dorgu hasn't escaped Amorim's criticism either, with the boss highlighting the full-back's 'anxiety' after the international break. The Danish star had impressed for his nation during their World Cup qualifying campaign, netting the equaliser against Scotland in a crucial encounter.

Despite the 4-2 defeat, Amorim spotted Dorgu's talent but admitted feeling anxious watching the youngster perform. Following United's 1-0 defeat to Everton earlier in November, the 40-year-old said: "He needs to be calmer playing the game.

"You can feel the anxiety every time Patrick touches the ball. I can feel the anxiety. You remember the shot against Everton. That was easier than the decision he had to make [playing for Denmark] against Scotland.
"He made a great decision, and I saw it when he played in Italy. But here it is different, and sometimes the pressure is hard for them in the beginning, but he has time to improve."
Summer signing Cunha has also experienced Amorim's public criticism this season. The Brazilian, who arrived in June for £62.5million, struggled initially to find the net in United colours.

His breakthrough moment came against Brighton in October, when he scored in a 4-2 victory for the Red Devils at Old Trafford. However, Amorim emphasised at the time that the forward needed to prioritise the team performance over personal statistics.

When Cunha was restored to the starting lineup for United's stalemate with West Ham earlier in December, Amorim said: "I think he has more levels to go. He is in a different club, different pressure, but I think he copes with that really well.

"He was struggling because he was not scoring and he was thinking too much about the numbers. The influence that he has in the team is so important for us, but I think Cunha has so much to grow defensively and offensively."
Whilst Amorim isn't shy about criticising his players throughout the campaign, it's evident that this approach is balanced with compassion and a genuine desire to see his squad flourish.

headline: Man Utd dressing room opinion of Alejandro Garnacho was revealed by ex-team-mate
body: Bruno Fernandes believed that Alejandro Garnacho didn't have "the best attitude" during his time at Manchester United. The 21-year-old winger secured a switch to Premier League rivals Chelsea during the summer after a bitter falling-out with Ruben Amorim.

The Argentinian found himself in the manager's bad books after publicly criticising his lack of playing time in the Europa League final, effectively dismissing the Portuguese boss's tactical approach. However, it wasn't only the boss who Garnacho rubbed up the wrong way, as club skipper Fernandes questioned the youngster's mindset while he was still at Old Trafford.

After the winger netted the winning goal in a Europa League encounter against Real Sociedad in 2022, the midfielder didn't hold back with his assessment of Garnacho. Fernandes said: "He was good but he knows we expect a lot from him.
"He's still really young, doing really well. At the beginning of the season, he was not at his best. On the [pre-season] tour he did not have the best attitude.
"That's why he didn't get his chance until now. He's getting his chances because he's training better, he's having the correct attitude."

This wasn't the sole occasion that Garnacho irritated his teammates, as The Sun reported in September that numerous influential figures in the United changing room attempted to address the young striker's approach.
Seasoned players, including Casemiro and Harry Maguire, were amongst those who tried to mentor Garnacho, though their efforts ultimately proved unsuccessful.

Following United's 1-0 defeat to Tottenham in the Europa League final, Garnacho said: "Until we reached the final, I played every round. And I played 20 minutes today – I don't know. I'm going to try to enjoy the summer and see what happens next."

He also criticised the club's Premier League campaign, adding: "Obviously it's hard for everyone. Our season was s***. We didn't beat anyone in the league. We lacked a lot of things. When you don't score goals, you always need more."
The Athletic reports that Amorim was furious and told Garnacho: "You better hope you have a good agent this summer," during a training ground exchange before their final match against Aston Villa.

After his £40million transfer to the Blues in the summer, the 21-year-old was swift to express gratitude to the club and its fans for his time in Manchester. He said: "Dear Mánchester. After an unforgettable five years, this special chapter in my life now comes to a close. We have created moments that will stay with me forever, and I'm very grateful for this.

"To the coaches, staff, and my teammates, thank you for believing in me. Every time I wore the badge, I gave everything I had. I leave proud of what we achieved together and excited for what's to come. Wishing the club nothing but success for the future, while I look forward to giving my all in the next chapter of my career."

Since his move to Stamford Bridge, Garnacho has yet to fully demonstrate his true potential for his new team, netting once and providing two assists in the league. Across all competitions, the Argentinian has made 13 appearances in total, scoring just twice, with his other goal coming in a 2-2 stalemate against Qarabag in the Champions League.

headline: Andre Onana drops Man Utd future hint ahead of January transfer window - 'Trust me'
body: Andre Onana has hinted that he's ready to end his Manchester United nightmare and sign for Trabzonspor on a permanent basis. Onana, 29, joined for the Turkish side in September on a season-long loan.

The goalkeeper had fallen down to third in the pecking order at Old Trafford, starting just one of United's opening four games this season prior to departing. Ruben Amorim had installed Altay Bayindir as his No.1 before signing Senne Lammens, who's been ever present since his £18.2million move from Royal Antwerp.

Amorim's decision prompted Onana to leave on a temporary basis, but it could now become permanent. "I'm very happy, trust me. I'm living the best period of my life. I can't complain, I'm very happy to be here," the Cameroonian said.

"Sometimes I'm driving and a car cuts in front of me. 'Onana, stop, I want a photo.' I think to myself, 'Yes, but we can do this in another way.' But when they see me, they're happy, and so am I. It was difficult at first, but now I understand.
"They are my men, I love them, and I love this feeling. Because they are very passionate. It's a wonderful thing. It's something you can't describe if you're not here.
"But the time I've spent here has been perfect for me. I'm happy to be here. It's a different lifestyle, but it's great. Truly incredible, amazing."
Onana has played all 13 Super Lig matches since coming into the team. Trabzonspor are currently third in the table, seven points behind leaders Galatasaray and four behind second-placed Fenerbahce.

Although the former Ajax star has impressed, manager Fatih Tekke is concerned about how many risks he takes on the ball. Speaking to 61Saat, Tekke revealed: "I have been warning Andre for two weeks; he is someone we like, and he knows this.

"He is one of the best when the ball is at his feet, but football requires immense attention. Moments are critical. Last week, he made two risky moves. He can break down the opponent, but a single mistake could have led to a very different outcome today."

Trabzonspor president Ertugrul Dogan is also a big fan. "As soon as he landed on Trabzon with his family, it was clear to us that he was a professional, and comfortable to play here. He shows true character," Dogan told HT Spor.

"Our young goalkeepers are very happy to have him here, After every training, he is almost giving them a private lesson, and he is not doing it because he was asked to, but because it is his character to do so."

headline: Man Utd's dream January transfer window: Marcus Rashford seals early exit as England star joins
body: Ruben Amorim's options seem to be limited as the January transfer window approaches, but Manchester United are still in a position to compete in the market. With Africa Cup of Nations commitments and injuries already taking their toll on the squad, a shake-up could be beneficial.

Bruno Fernandes' recent injury is likely to result in the longest absence he's had since moving to England nearly six years ago. This is compounded by the absences of Bryan Mbeumo, Amad Diallo and Noussair Mazraoui, who are all currently competing in Morocco.

While this may not be the happy ending many envisaged for Rashford at United, it could alleviate a lot of pressure for the club. With his ties in Manchester seemingly irreparable, a swift resolution would be a positive outcome at this point.

Rashford's value is high due to his impressive form at Barcelona, who have the option to secure a bargain £28million deal for the forward. Despite their financial difficulties, it's still within the Spanish powerhouse's means to afford such a fee, although it may be optimistic to expect a deal to be finalised this far ahead of schedule.

Clearing Rashford's hefty £300,000-a-week salary from the payroll would be a significant relief for United's board, even if Barca are footing the bill during his loan spell. This would equate to a saving of around £16m over the remaining two years of Rashford's contract, excluding any transfer fee.

If Barca were to decide Rashford had earned a permanent move as soon as next month, it would provide United with an immediate cash boost to reinvest. And the amount would be appreciated following a summer of heavy expenditure.

Securing established stars in the winter is always challenging, but Conor Gallagher presents an enticing prospect. Not only does the ex-Chelsea player have the potential to break into the starting XI, but he also fits the profile of player United currently need and could be available in January, possibly via an initial loan deal.

After an impressive debut season at Atletico Madrid, Gallagher has fallen out of favour under Diego Simeone. He's only made eight starts in all competitions during the first half of the season, with suggestions a fee of around £26m could secure his departure from Spain.

A versatile midfielder who can fill various roles, Gallagher would certainly ease the burden during Fernandes' absence. And with rumours once again circulating that the United captain could depart next year, signing a replacement now would demonstrate excellent foresight.

The only drawback to bringing Gallagher on board is that it could further hinder the opportunities for Kobbie Mainoo to get game time. However, it seems increasingly likely Amorim doesn't have immediate plans to promote the academy graduate in any case.

Despite the summer signings of Mbeumo, Benjamin Sesko and Matheus Cunha, United's attacking options still appear somewhat thin. Sesko's recent injury exposed a worrying lack of depth in the forward line, a gap that Joshua Zirkzee and Cunha haven't quite managed to fill in recent weeks.

Koln gem Said El Mala isn't a natural frontman, and Amorim's favoured 3-4-2-1 formation doesn't necessarily accommodate wingers of his variety. However, at 19 years old, the right manager could shape him into a formidable threat in a modified role, and his age profile would mean the manager could bide his time developing the player.

El Mala's 6'2" stature may seem awkward out wide, but he has been used as a centre forward by Koln on occasion. The teenager has netted six goals and provided three assists in just 15 Bundesliga appearances this season, showing a natural goal-scoring instinct that could flourish if nurtured at Old Trafford.

Once again, United would be wise to act swiftly as Bayern Munich, Barcelona, Manchester City and Tottenham are among the clubs vying for his signature. His signing could come with a hefty price tag given he's contracted at Koln until 2030, but El Mala may be the kind of talent who becomes a key figure at the club for years to come.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United manager Ruben Amorim makes Kobbie Mainoo transfer admission
body: Ruben Amorim admitted it would be "hard" to sanction a loan exit for Kobbie Mainoo if Manchester United cannot replace him. Mainoo has not started for United in the Premier League this season. The youngster was potentially in line to receive his first start against Aston Villa last weekend, but he picked up a calf injury in training and was ruled out of that match in Birmingham.

The 20-year-old requested to leave on loan in the summer transfer window and could request to leave again in the January window when he returns from the sidelines. However, Bruno Fernandes picked up a muscle injury against Aston Villa and United's midfield options will be lighter during his absence.
Amorim admitted the moving parts could mean a potential request to leave on loan from Mainoo would be rejected. "If we are not getting someone [in], then we are shorter," he said.

"Even with a full squad, we are shorter when something can happen here. We are a club with a big responsibility, we are dealing with all these issues and in your head, my head, and everyone's heads, we need to win every game, it doesn't matter, there are no excuses, so it's going to be hard for someone to leave the club if we don't get a substitution [new signing]."
When asked whether Mainoo could kick on when he returns to fitness in the absence of Fernandes, Amorim said: "Kobbie Mainoo will have the opportunity that he has all the time.

"He played in different positions and we talk about the position of Casemiro - he can do that. He can play, if you play with three, like we did in the last game, the position of Mason Mount in this game, he can play there.
"He is going to be the future of Manchester United. That is my feeling, so he just needs to wait for his chance and everything can change in football, even in two days."

United's target is to seal a return to European football this season, but Amorim would not predict whether his squad could qualify for the Champions League if no new signings are made in the January window.
"I think it's hard to talk about that," he said. "What I can say is we have the potential to do more, and I think I can do more with the team, and I can help the team to be better. That I can say.

"If it's top four, it's different in our club, not everything around our club is so simple. We have the talent to reach it, but there is so much more than that in the team. The only thing I can say is that if we have the full squad, I think I can help them to play better and we can be better in the future."

headline: RAILSTON: Ruben Amorim gives update on two Manchester United players out of contract next summer
body: Ruben Amorim is "happy" with Casemiro and Harry Maguire, but could not answer whether a decision had been made on both players' futures ahead of their contract expiry at the end of the season. Casemiro, 33, has enjoyed a renaissance at Old Trafford, becoming an important player again after a period of not starting games under Amorim.

The Brazilian has started 14 games out of a possible 17 in the Premier League this term, leading to speculation that his stay in Manchester could be extended beyond the summer. United have the option to extend Casemiro's contract by 12 months, but he is the highest earner in the dressing room and he would continue to earn the same salary if the clause were triggered.

Maguire has made just four starts in the Premier League this season and has not played since picking up a hamstring injury against Tottenham on November 8. There is no option to extend Maguire's deal by 12 months because that option was already triggered by United last year.

When asked whether Amorim had an update on the pair, he said: "No, there is no decision, we have a lot to do. We need to understand what is going to happen in the next season because we need to understand there are European games, and what we are doing.
"So we have so much to do at this moment. We are not thinking about that. We will think just think about the next game."

Amorim was asked whether he would like to keep both players and responded: "I'm really happy with them, but I don't know what is going to happen, so we will see what will happen until the end of the season, what position we will be, and then we will see."

And discussing whether the uncertainty could impact Casemiro's form, Amorim said: "It's not that situation, I'm not saying whether he is staying or not. Then when I see Casemiro training, if everyone trained like him, if everyone is so focused on the detail, even in set-piece training.

"Even when they are playing 10 versus the goalkeeper and the movement that he makes. Imagine in the game, we will be a top team. If everybody works like Casemiro. And when I say work, it's not just about the running, it's the focus, and you can understand why that guy won five Champions Leagues.
"If you pay attention to everything that he does, with contract or with no contract, he's a top player."

headline: How Man United should line up vs Newcastle in Boxing Day Premier League fixture
body: Manchester United return to Premier League action tonight for the only Boxing Day fixture in the division with Newcastle the visitors to Old Trafford. United will be hoping they can get a win following the defeat to Aston Villa on Sunday. The loss meant the Reds missed the chance to move up to fifth in the table, but due to playing before everyone else this weekend the opportunity is still there.

Ruben Amorim will be without Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo for the fixture. Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt are also missing but could return next Tuesday against Wolverhampton Wanderers. Casemiro is available having served his one-game suspension.
MEN Sport has asked their United writers to pick their team for tonight's fixture under the lights.
Tyrone Marshall

United's squad is desperately stretched again and there are very few options available to Amorim to mix things up. There will be a temptation to bring Lisandro Martinez back but it's Leny Yoro's place that is vulnerable and the question has to be whether Martinez can play on the right, so for now that back three remains unchanged.

Diogo Dalot and Patrick Dorgu are the only available wing-backs. In midfield, it has to be Manuel Ugarte in the deep role and then Casemiro next to him, but it's not a combination that inspires. Newcastle will fancy winning the midfield battle as they so often do against United.
There aren't many attacking options either, so Mason Mount, Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko go again. Cunha is at least in magnificent form at the moment.
Steven Railston
Martinez was good from off the bench last weekend, but he played in midfield. I would stick with the same back three, although I would make a big change in midfield for this festive game.

Ugarte is well below the standard required and I would give Jack Fletcher a chance to start alongside Casemiro. Ugarte was poor again at Villa Park and we've seen enough of him to suggest he's not at the level required.
Fletcher's cameo was encouraging and it would be exciting to see what he can offer from the start.
Jack Flintham
What will be concerning Amorim going into this game is who will be providing the creativity next to Casemiro. That's why moving Mount back should be tempting for United this Boxing Day.

Replacing him in the No.10 role in this scenario would be Joshua Zirkzee. The Dutchman has struggled at United but his better performances have come when he has played in a deeper role and not been asked to lead the line.
Otherwise, it should be the same team that did little wrong at Villa - other than not winning.

headline: Man United line-up vs Newcastle predicted as midfield star returns but Amorim faces problem
body: Newcastle have endured a rollercoaster season of their own so far, but just one defeat in their last seven games means they are just three points behind United.

Senne Lammens will start in goal tonight. Leny Yoro had a tough afternoon at Villa Park but he seems set to continue in the back three alongside Ayden Heaven and Luke Shaw. Lisandro Martinez is also an option after he stepped up his return to full match fitness against Villa.

Casemiro was suspended against Villa so he will come back into the team, and Manuel Ugarte could be handed another chance given the lack of alternative central midfield options. Starting two defensive midfielders at Old Trafford is far from ideal for Amorim but the injury problems he's facing at the moment mean he has little choice, with Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo both ruled out. Diogo Dalot will start at right wing-back with Patrick Dorgu on the left.

Mason Mount has looked much improved this season and he can start in one of the two No.10 roles next to Matheus Cunha. United need more from Benjamin Sesko and a goal today could be the fillip his season is in need of.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Ruben Neves tussle, Antoine Semenyo latest, wonderkid link
body: Good morning, Manchester United fans and Merry Christmas from us all at the MEN.
Ruben Amorim's side are back in action later this evening when they take on Newcastle United at Old Trafford and we're edging closer to the January transfer window opening.
United have made a stark improvement compared to last season and are just outside the Champions League places at the time of writing.
Investment into the squad in January could be make or break for Amorim in their quest to return to European football.
United have been repeatedly linked with January transfer swoops for the likes of Carlos Baleba, Elliot Anderson and Adam Wharton with central midfield a priority position to address.
A number of players could also depart, with uncertainty around Kobbie Mainoo's future at the club having fallen down the pecking order under Amorim.
We'll have all the latest Man Utd transfer news and speculation in our live blog below.
Renato Bittar has ruled out a potential loan move for his client Diego Leon away from Old Trafford in the January transfer window.
The youngster, who signed for United in the summer, has been linked with a move to Ligue 1 club OGC Nice, who are also owned by Ineos.
However, Bittar expects Leon to remain at Old Trafford for the entire season.
"We’re always in touch with the club, and Diego León will stay at United for the entire season; he’s not going anywhere," he told ABC Cardinal.
"In my opinion, Diego León should stay at Manchester United. He’s playing for the U21s and alternating as a substitute [on the bench] in the first team."
The Athletic claim personal terms will not be a problem between Joshua Zirkzee and AS Roma ahead of a potential loan move to Serie A.
The Dutch forward has struggled for regular game time this season and is said to be keen on a return to Italy in an attempt to bolster his World Cup hops this summer.
Intermediaries are said to have proposed a loan with an obligation to buy, though no club-to-club talks have taken place.
Any deal would have to wait until after AFCON when United are back to full strength.
Manchester United know they'll face competition from Pep Guardiola's side if they want to sign Bournemouth forward Antoine Semenyo.
The Cherries forward has reportedly made it clear he'd prefer a move to Man City despite interest from United, Liverpool and several other Premier League sides.
Chelsea reportedly made contact with Semenyo earlier this week, but have since pulled out of any future deal.
Semenyo is available for £65million next month with his reported release clause activating.
Manchester United have been linked with a move for Corinthians wonderkid Breno Bido, but reports in Brazil claim a move away from his home country is not likely at present.
The 20-year-old's agent said he'd spoke to several 'big European clubs' but there have not yet been any offers.

Speaking to Globo Esporte, Fernando Brito said: "From the big European clubs, I don’t know which one I haven’t spoken to. Any club you mention, at some point, we have already had some enquiry, relationship or contact. That doesn’t mean it will turn into a formal offer.

"The moment for Breno to go to Europe will come. That’s a fact. But we’re in no rush. The great challenge is not going to Europe or making a big sale. The real challenge is sustaining a new project, like we did at Corinthians."

Manchester United, Atlético Madrid and Sporting have all been touted as possible destinations for the midfielder, who has a release clause of €100m (£87.3m) to foreign clubs, though his agent admits the market will determine his value.
"The market decides that," he said. "Corinthians will want to raise the price and the buying club will want to lower it. We’re here to balance that.
"He’s a special kid, with a great heart, humble, and with a lot still to conquer. He’s not only thinking about transfer value."
Manchester United, Tottenham Hotspur and Newcastle United have all been linked with a move for Al Hilal midfielder Ruben Neves.
That's according to Turkish outlet, Sabah, who claim United are in the race to sign the Portuguese international.
Earlier this week, Spanish media outlet AS claimed any club interested in the former Wolves playmaker would face a transfer tussle with Real Madrid.
The 28-year-old midfielder is in the final six months of his contract in Saudi Arabia and there has been no breakthrough regarding fresh terms.
Good morning United fans and welcome to our live blog!
We'll be covering all the latest transfer news and speculation from across the globe as Ruben Amorim's side look to kick on in the second half of the season.
The Reds endured a torrid season in 2024-25, but have made a considerable improvement in terms of points tally this season.
Stay with us throughout the day for all the latest from Old Trafford.

headline: Man United have two games to avoid fresh Ruben Amorim nightmare scenario after Casemiro blow
body: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim faces a potential selection headache with defender Patrick Dorgu walking a suspension tightrope. The Danish full-back is one booking away from serving a one-match ban after accumulating four yellow cards so far this season.
The United boss was forced to alter his squad for the 2-1 defeat to Aston Villa last time out, with Casemiro sidelined after totting up five bookings, following his booking against Bournemouth.
Already, the Portuguese needs all of his squad available and firing after losing Noussair Mazraoui, Bryan Mbeumo and Amad due to their involvement at the Africa Cup of Nations.
Dorgu, 21, has made 16 appearances in the Premier League this season, starting in half of those so far this term - registering an assist last time out at Villa Park.

The full-back has avoided booking in each of his last six outings for United and will need to continue doing so in their next two outings against Newcastle and Wolves, in order to avoid suspension with the Premier League bookings reset set to occur after matchday 19.

The Football Association's disciplinary rules state any player who earns five bookings from their side's first 19 Premier League matches of a season will have to serve a one-match ban in the same competition.
If a player accumulates 10 yellow cards in Premier League matches up to and including their side's 32nd fixture, they will serve a two-match suspension.
Dorgu is the only player at risk of a suspension, while Mbeumo is next with three yellow cards.
Bruno Fernandes, Diogo Dalot and Luke Shaw are clear of serving a suspension as they sit on two cautions each.
However, Fernandes could miss up to a month of action for United after being forced off during the interval against Aston Villa.

It adds further complications for Amorim with an already depleted squad, which allowed for Shea Lacey and Jack Fletcher to make their senior debuts for United after being introduced as second-half substitutes at Villa Park.
The Portuguese called for players to step up to the plate in the absence of their figurehead and other senior members.
"It is impossible to replace Bruno," said Amorim. "I said that this morning to the team.
"We need to take the good thing, if there is a good thing on that - a lot of people need to step up."

headline: Manchester United handed Morgan Rogers January transfer verdict - 'Would be a dream'
body: Morgan Rogers has been identified as Manchester United's 'dream signing' ahead of the January transfer window. The 23 year old Rogers is enjoying the finest form of his career and maintained his exceptional run during Aston Villa's 2-1 home triumph over United last Sunday.

The England international netted both of Villa's goals; the opener was a magnificent curled strike from range whilst the second came via a similar finish from a closer position. The result extended Villa's winning streak to 10 matches as they chase the title, and following Bruno Fernandes' injury departure, it highlighted to Red Devils manager Ruben Amorim precisely the type of player his squad lacks.

This assessment comes from former United forward Louis Saha, who believes the club should launch an ambitious pursuit of Rogers. Speaking to FootItalia, Saha said: "In January, I see a need for a replacement who can spark our midfield creativity,".

"In addition to Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount, there's a need for speed in the creativity there. I think Conor Gallagher would've been a good signing, he has the legs and the power, I'd also love to see Morgan Rogers at United.

"He definitely has this power, he reminds me a bit of Joelinton. That kind of power, and still very technical, and able to go forward. Having that kind of presence in the midfield is so important.", he told
"I see Rogers as being able to actually bomb forward, but also get pressed and keep the ball, giving time for other players to move into different positions. He is the type of player United need.

"It's a very interesting profile that's rare in the sense that a lot of players are very athletic, but in terms of making the right choice with that athleticism, that's not easy. So I can see Rogers as being a dream signing."

Significantly, Rogers shares a history with United's director of football, Jason Wilcox, dating back to their Manchester City days. Wilcox was overseeing City's academy when they splashed out £4.3million to secure the services of a 16 year old Rogers from West Bromwich Albion in 2019, meaning the forward will already be familiar with key figures in the United setup.

Numerous City academy products are thriving across the Premier League, with Cole Palmer being the standout example. United would undoubtedly relish the opportunity to benefit from their rivals' misjudgement, but any club pursuing Rogers will find Villa demanding a steep price.

"Morgan Rogers is performing fantastically, but he has started the season not getting (goalscoring) numbers but playing well," Unai Emery said after beating United. "Always doing his task, always with the commitment he's showing, with the attitude he has, played each match.

"Today he did the same and scored goals, of course. He is the protagonist. I'm so, so happy because he's a fighter. He's a good guy, very good guy. His commitment with Aston Villa is massive, and his attitude every day is really fantastic. And when he's getting numbers like today, of course we are very proud of everybody, but especially today with him."

headline: Inside the Manchester United and Man City interest in Antoine Semenyo
body: Bournemouth forward Antoine Semenyo is likely to be the talk of the January transfer window with the Premier League's top clubs all vying for his signature next month. On New Year's Day, a release clause of £65m will go live for a limited time and both Manchester United and Manchester City are weighing up activating it.

Semenyo has scored eight goals and bagged three assists this season and while he could be available in the summer, no team looks willing to take this risk. Reports suggest City are Semenyo's preferred destination but United are not thought to be out of the running.

The 25-year-old is the latest star player ready to make a move to a top club but exactly who that will be remains to be seen. So with Semenyo's future firmly in the balance, MEN Sport has asked United and City writers Tyrone Marshall and Simon Bajkowski for the state of play at the Manchester clubs surrounding Semenyo and transfers.
Can they afford it?

Yes. United’s financial situation is much improved from a year ago and they are now more comfortable with their compliance with Profit and Sustainability rules, which are coming to an end anyway. They spent more than expected in the summer and much of it was on what United saw as favourable payment terms, so they can make this deal happen, especially as it was a move they had planned for the summer anyway.
Would he want to go to United ahead of other Premier League clubs in the Champions League?

United feel they are in with a chance so the indications are he is open to it. They aren’t making smooth progress towards qualifying next season either but you feel that it is there for them if they can put the pedal down. There is still an attraction to playing for this club, despite what has happened in the last few years.
Does he fit into Ruben Amorim's rigid system as another 10 or wing-back?

I think he fits in as both and that will be a big attraction to United. If everyone is fit and available, I would expect him to get in the team as a left wing-back, with Amad on the right and Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo as the No.10s.

That would give United significant firepower and a much more attacking outlook. But Semenyo can play on both flanks and through the middle and the fact he could cover so many of those positions in Amorim’s system makes him doubly attractive.
Who is he an upgrade on?

As a left wing-back, he is an upgrade on everyone. Diogo Dalot has done a respectable job there and Patrick Dorgu looked better at Villa Park, but it is still a problem position. Semenyo could fill it. And as an option as another No.10 he is clearly better than Joshua Zirkzee as well. He would be a major upgrade at left wing-back and as the third or fourth No.10.
Where does Semenyo fit among all the attacking options?

Semenyo is a wide option in a team that is not flush with them. Pep Guardiola has moved away from using his wingers really this season, even moving Jeremy Doku inside. Semenyo can play on either flank and so could give City extra options of playing but at the same time he will also be expected to add extra dimensions to his game.
Who is he an upgrade on?

In terms of the current squad, he would definitely move ahead of Oscar Bobb. The Norwegian hasn't recovered from the leg fracture that robbed him of a breakthrough at the beginning of the 2023/24 campaign, so is looking vulnerable in the January window. Semenyo would also be expected to challenge with Savinho - who he has outperformed this season with Bournemouth - and Doku for a place in the team.
What does Guardiola like in Semenyo that's similar to past successful City players?

More than anything with a January signing, you want somebody who can fit straight into the team. Semenyo is a bit different in the sense he's only moving in January because of opportunity for him and Bournemouth, but the fact he is Premier League proven is perfect for a manager looking to make sure he has a squad capable of going far in all competitions.
Semenyo has shown he's versatile and can play in different systems so there is plenty to like.
Simon is the MEN's Chief Manchester City Writer. He joined the MEN sport desk in 2013 and has covered City home and away since 2016, reporting on Pep Guardiola's time at the club.

headline: Former Manchester United star supported after £55m transfer challenge
body: Eddie Howe believes that the criticism of £55million signing Anthony Elanga has been too quick off the mark this season. The winger, who joined from Nottingham Forest, has only sporadically displayed the brilliance he demonstrated at the City Ground and is yet to find the back of the net for Newcastle United.
Despite providing just one Premier League assist and setting up a single goal in the Champions League, Howe is confident that Elanga will make a significant impact in 2026.

During Saturday's 2-2 draw with Chelsea, Elanga carved open the opposition defence but chose to shoot instead of passing to a team-mate at the Gallowgate End. This decision led to a video of the incident going viral on social media, but Howe doesn't believe this accurately represents the former Manchester United player's abilities.

Per Chronicle Live, Howe said: "With Anth, it is really strange. If you put all of his best moments together in a Newcastle shirt, you'd see a showreel of a player who has some unbelievable attributes, and he's done some really, really good things for the team.

"Even the moment on Saturday (vs Chelsea), not many other players would have been able to elevate themselves into that position because they would not have his speed or athleticism to get there in the first place.", reports Chronicle Live.
"So I think sometimes we are very quick to analyse things negatively rather than the positive.
"Yes, the end part was just slightly missing.
"I think that has been the thing that has held Anthony back from getting the recognition he deserves."
Howe has expressed confidence in Elanga's potential to shine in the new year, believing that once he's fully acclimated to his new club, he'll regain the form he demonstrated at Nottingham Forest.
He stated: "I think better things are to come in the future from him. The end product, goals and assists you know that he will want, we will want from him.
"But it is there, and the tools are there.
"A lot of it comes with feeling and confidence and the belonging aspect.
"When you come to Newcastle or a new club the quicker you can feel all of those things the better time you will have.
"So I really believe in him and that has never wavered from me.
"I see the professional he is and how hard he works behind the scenes, and how well he wants to do, he is one of our best trainers every single day.
"When you put all those things together then I believe really strongly will have a great time."
Elanga looks set to play a part on Boxing Day when Newcastle visit Old Trafford.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United give Bruno Fernandes injury update as double blow confirmed vs Newcastle
body: Ruben Amorim has confirmed Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo will be unavailable for Manchester United's game against Newcastle due to injury. Fernandes started against Aston Villa last weekend, but he was brought off at half-time after holding his hamstring. Mainoo was absent from the squad in Birmingham after picking up an injury in training.

Amorim confirmed Fernandes had suffered a muscle injury following the Villa defeat, but the United boss provided a further team news update during his Christmas Eve press conference. Speaking about Fernandes and Mainoo, he said: "No, not for this game [Newcastle], they are recovering. I don’t think it will take a lot of time, I think Kobbie will return faster than Bruno."

When asked when Fernandes would return, Amorim responded: "I don’t want to say. I have an idea, of course, but let’s see." Amorim was asked about filling the void and said: "We have other players, we need to maybe see different ways of playing. I think Jack Fletcher did a very good job, and that’s why when we have these opportunities, we need to give space to guys like Jack and the other ones."

Fernandes has only missed two United matches due to injury during his time at Old Trafford. The midfielder's other enforced absence was due to illness against Tottenham in March 2022. Harry Maguire has not played since picking up a hamstring injury against Tottenham Hotspur on November 8, while Matthijs de Ligt last played against Crystal Palace on November 30 due to a back injury.
Both Maguire and De Ligt remain unavailable. "We are still working with them," Amorim said about the pair. "They are not available for this one, but let’s see for the next one."

Casemiro will be available to face Newcastle on Boxing Day after serving a suspension last weekend. The Brazilian was forced to sit out the visit to Birmingham after picking up his fifth yellow card of the season.
Amorim will oversee his second game without Bryan Mbeumo and Amad, who both started in the 4-4 draw against Bournemouth before travelling to the Africa Cup of Nations.
Noussair Mazraoui is representing the AFCON host nation Morocco at the tournament.

headline: RAILSTON: Ruben Amorim challenges two Manchester United players to 'step up' amid Bruno Fernandes absence
body: Ruben Amorim has challenged Lisandro Martinez and Luke Shaw to "step up" in the dressing room in the absence of Bruno Fernandes, who picked up a muscle injury against Aston Villa. Fernandes was brought off at half-time against Villa, and he will be unavailable when United take on Newcastle on Boxing Day.

Fernandes has been an ever-present in the starting team since his arrival in Manchester in January 2020, but Amorim will have to manage without his captain. Amorim confirmed Fernandes would miss the Boxing Day clash at his pre-Newcastle press conference, and he discussed how the team would cope without the Portugal international in the side.

"I'm confident we can win any game," said Amorim. "Of course, we have some problems, but we need to believe in the team, even without many players in this moment. I believe in the team and believe we can win any game.

"It's more difficult, but I trust in my players, and if we are really focused, we can win. I think it's impossible to replace Bruno, but I said to the team we need to take the good thing, if there is a good thing, that a lot of people need to step up."

Amorim added: "If you see it's not just the creation [from Fernandes], it's every set-piece when the guy is organising sometimes the team, which is a good opportunity for everyone to step up. They need to understand we cannot rely on one player for everything, and sometimes we rely on Bruno in the organisation, in the creation. We have lost Bruno, Amad and Bryan for set-pieces, so this is massive for the team, but it's an opportunity for other players to step up and show leadership in the team.

"He understands every position on the field, every detail and every set-piece; he is always the guy who is telling the other guys where they should be. That is a very good opportunity for guys like Licha [Martinez] and Luke Shaw, all these guys, we need to step up to have more leaders in the group."
United's injuries opened the door for Jack Fletcher and Shea Lacey to make their debuts against Villa. "They are normal, they are good kids," said Amorim when asked how the pair have reacted.

"The behaviour they have shown during these weeks is really good, but I don't have that feeling that they are a little bit different because they play for Manchester United. They are really focused, and they are preparing the game. They believe they can play, so that is a good feeling."

Amorim was without multiple key players at Villa Park last weekend, but Newcastle have a dismal away record this season. headline: Manchester United handed Bruno Fernandes injury timeline update after fresh Ruben Amorim problem
body: Manchester United captain Bruno Fernandes is facing at least one month out of action after suffering from an injury in his side's 2-1 defeat at Aston Villa on Sunday afternoon.
That's according to The Telegraph, who report that the club captain sustained a "suspected soft-tissue injury", which saw him forced off at half-time at Villa Park.
The Portuguese playmaker was seen struggling through the first half of the match, with the second half seeing him replaced by Lisandro Martinez, who took up the midfield role instead.

The injury for Fernandes comes as a blow to Man United at the worst possible time, with three game-changers in Bryan Mbeumo, Amad, and Noussair Mazraoui all away on international duty with their respective nations for the Africa Cup of Nations over the next month or so.
That has already seen Ruben Amorim dealt a depleted squad, which was evident with his reliance on younger players in the defeat on Sunday.
The loss of Fernandes is a particularly huge blow, considering how crucial he has been to their recent uptick in form, picking up five goals and seven assists from his deeper midfield role.
Speaking about the injury after the game, Amorim said: "I think it's a soft-tissue injury so it's going to be a while. He is a guy who is always fit so we hope he can recover well. We will see.
"It's an injury and sometimes it’s bad luck or something else at the same time. You can never control these things.
"We will need to find solutions and we cannot use anything as an excuse. We need to prepare all the guys that we have for the next game.
"No one is going to remember these problems, so let’s cope with that. It will make us stronger."

Mainoo was absent from the defeat at Villa Park, due to a minor injury picked up in training, which meant he couldn't be the immediate Fernandes replacement on Sunday, but could be for Boxing Day's clash with Newcastle United.
With yet another injury issue, there are some big games for Amorim coming up over the next month that could see the club captain out of action.

With United's last realistic chance of silverware coming in the FA Cup, the loss of Fernandes for the Brighton clash could be huge, on top of his absence for matches against rivals such as Leeds, Manchester City, and Arsenal.

headline: MARSHALL: Ruben Amorim needs to change his tune on Manchester United transfers after nightmare 24 hours
body: When Ruben Amorim looks under his tree on Christmas Day, he is likely to be disappointed. The Manchester United head coach could do with finding a couple of midfielders wrapped up, and no pair of socks will make up for the disappointment of not finding Elliot Anderson or Adam Wharton ready to pop out of a box.

Amorim suggested on Friday that United were unlikely to sign a midfielder in January, but then he didn't expect to finish the game at Aston Villa with Lisandro Martinez and Jack Fletcher in the middle of the pitch. Christmas should be a time of giving, but it's been a costly week for Amorim and United.

Having seen Noussair Mazraoui, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo depart for the Africa Cup of Nations, he saw Kobbie Mainoo limp out of training on Saturday and Bruno Fernandes pull up at the end of the first half. Casemiro's suspension left the outmatched Manuel Ugarte as the only senior midfielder left standing.

Ugarte has fallen out of favour under Amorim, and at times at Villa Park, you could see why. His work in possession was particularly poor. He had to fill Fernandes' box-to-box role in the second half and it's difficult to make a case for a team stretched to that degree getting a result against the Premier League's in-form team.

That run of form is built on shaky foundations if you believe the data geeks, but Morgan Rogers is doing his best to condemn the boffins to the bin this season. He is making a habit of scoring stunners, so the solution is to make sure he can't shoot. Instead, Leny Yoro was so busy handing out gifts he should have been wearing a white beard.

He was too passive against Rogers and paid the price twice. It undid a lot of the good work that United put in at Villa Park. For the second game running, they created chances and looked like a threat going forward, but failed to win. It is now two wins in eight.

Villa came out of the blocks quickly, as you would expect of a team on a run of nine successive wins. Ayden Heaven twice had to block shots from Ollie Watkins, Senne Lammens made a save from John McGinn and Rogers reacted quickly to flick an Ian Maatsen drive towards goal in the six-yard box, only to see it squirm just wide.

United settled their rocking ship, however, and should have led by the midway point of the half. Benjamin Sesko found himself in on goal only to be denied by a sprawling save from Emiliano Martinez. A minute later, it was a clever pass from Matheus Cunha that sent Sesko in, but he took a heavy touch when trying to round Martinez, when he should have attempted to lift a first-time finish.

In a stodgy half, it was Rogers and Cunha who had looked like making something happen, and they delivered within minutes of each other. Rogers had nothing on when he picked up possession on the left touchline, but Yoro never got close to the Premier League's in-form player and let him drift into a shooting position, from where he picked his spot clinically.

Thankfully for United, Matty Cash was also in the Christmas spirit. He was caught napping by Patrick Dorgu, with the ball falling to Cunha. The Brazilian had plenty to do, but his unerring finish was measured to perfection.

The half-time loss of Fernandes was a hammer blow for United. The captain had stopped the game after clutching his hamstring, but continued until the break. He even had a goal-bound shot blocked by Ezri Konsa in that period, but couldn't continue. It meant Amorim had to raid his threadbare bench and the promotion of Martinez to midfield showed what he thought of the other options available to him.

Martinez settled into the game quickly, and United started the second half well, but were again undone by a moment of Rogers' magic. The finish was from a similar angle after the ball bounced clear to him, and again, Yoro was too cautious in trying to stop him. His two shots were worth a combined xG of 0.07 on the spreadsheet. Unfortunately for United, the game was being played on the pitch.

The consolation for Amorim was that his team was being beaten by stunners. So stretched were resources that the Portuguese called a truce with the academy, handing out two debuts, with Jack Fletcher and Shea Lacey coming off the bench.

Diogo Dalot forced Martinez into a save and Dorgu's follow-up was blocked by Cash. The recalled wing-back then stuck a cross on Cunha's head only for the Brazilian's effort to bounce wide. Lacey managed a shot on target from distance and Mount whipped a free-kick onto the roof of the net.
It was an afternoon when United could count themselves a little unlucky, but the results are flatlining again. Casemiro will return on Boxing Day. Who partners him is anyone's guess.
